text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns from work, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days or when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out why the man on the 10th floor takes the elevator down every morning and then, in the evening, goes to the 7th floor and walks up three flights, except on rainy days or when there are other people in the elevator.
Hmm, let's break this down.
First, every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor.
That makes sense because he's going to work.
But in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then walks up three floors.
Why not just go straight up to the 10th floor? Well, maybe there's a reason related to the elevator's behavior or building rules.
Wait, the problem mentions that on rainy days or when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.
So, on normal days without those conditions, he doesn't go all the way up.
Maybe the elevator has some limitations.
Perhaps the elevator only goes up to the 7th floor, or maybe it's programmed not to go beyond that unless certain conditions are met.
Let me think.
If the elevator can't go beyond the 7th floor under normal circumstances, then he has to take it down each time he wants to go up.
That would explain why he takes the elevator down every morning.

But then, why doesn't he just take the elevator up to the 10th floor in the evening?

Ah, perhaps the elevator is shared and has a rule where it stops at the 7th floor, maybe because someone else lives there or there's a maintenance stop.
So, when he takes the elevator in the evening, it only goes up to the 7th floor, and then he has to walk the remaining three floors.
But on rainy days or when others are in the elevator, he can override that limit and go all the way up to the 10th floor.
Wait, but why wouldn't he just take the elevator up to the 10th floor every time? Maybe the elevator has a maximum speed or time limit, and when it's raining or crowded, he can adjust it.

Or perhaps the elevator only goes up to the 7th floor unless it's empty, which would explain why he takes it down in the morning when it's likely to be empty and then in the evening, if it's full, he can go up.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator has a rule where it doesn't go above the 7th floor unless there's a specific request or condition met, like bad weather or when someone else is in it.
So, on normal days, he can't get the elevator to take him all the way up, hence he walks the stairs after the 7th floor.
So, putting it all together, the man takes the elevator down in the morning because it's the quickest way to the ground floor.

In the evening, he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor because the elevator might have a limit, perhaps due to building rules or elevator mechanics, and then he walks the remaining three floors because that's the only way to reach his apartment.
But on rainy days or when there are others in the elevator, he can override that limit and go all the way up to the 10th floor, which might be more convenient or necessary in those situations.
I think that's the main reason.
The elevator likely has a restriction, so he has to take it down each time he wants to go up, but on certain conditions, he can bypass that restriction.

</think>

The man takes the elevator down every morning because it's the quickest way to reach the ground floor.
In the evening, he rides the elevator up to the 7th floor, which is the limit it can reach under normal conditions, and then walks up the remaining three floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days or when others are in the elevator, he can go directly to the 10th floor, likely because the elevator can bypass its usual limit in these situations.
